overview_of_class:
We'll read poetry, fiction and drama analytically, with an eye toward identifying how these particular forms work, how through various linguistic means they produce meaning. We'll work primarily in a discussion format.

Readings may include works from the following: Martin Espada, Natasha Trethewey, Daboberto Gilb, Maxine Kumin, Emily Dickinson, Raymond Carver, George Saunders, Lucille Clifton, Haruki Murakami, Moliere, Sophocles, Sherman Alexie.
name: Introduction to Literature
title: SCS ENGLISH 113-CN-66 Introduction to Literature

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
We'll read poetry, fiction and drama analytically, with an eye toward identifying how these particular forms work, how through various linguistic means they produce meaning. We'll work primarily in a discussion format.

Readings may include works from the following: Martin Espada, Natasha Trethewey, Daboberto Gilb, Maxine Kumin, Emily Dickinson, Raymond Carver, George Saunders, Lucille Clifton, Haruki Murakami, Moliere, Sophocles, Sherman Alexie.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The main goals in this course are for students to develop a greater familiarity with poetry, fiction and drama as genres of writing, and to become familiar with a range of reading strategies for approaching these readings analytically, and to develop both in class discussion and in writing.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Classes will be primarily discussion based, with short introductory material at the beginning of each class. We'll also screen some brief selections in class from film productions of several of the plays.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: There will be three or four short (1-1.5 pp.) response papers, and three take-home midterms?one on poetry, one on drama and one on fiction. In-class class participation is an essential part of the course.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: We will use paperback editions of several plays and story collections, as well as a reference guide for literary terms, all of which will be available at Beck's Books in Evanston.
